did.unittitle: Leeser, Isaac and Pyke, E. Kingston, Jamacia, Letter from E. Pyke in Kingston, Jamaica to Isaac Leeser. In this letter, Pyke brings Leeser up to date on the progress of Jewish institutional matters on the island as well as on family events. He also lists the current subscribers to the Occident

Leeser, Isaac and Raphall, Morris J. New York, NY, A two page letter from Morris J. Raphall (1798-1868), publisher of the weekly "Hebrew Review," to Isaac Leeser, concerning one of Raphall's translations that is to be published in the Occident. The letter discusses his use of the English "you" vs. the Oriental "thou", and requests a proof prior to publishing

Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Isaac. Baltimore, MD, A letter from Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to his uncle Zalma Rehine in Baltimore, Maryland. The letter describes the flow of funds invovled in the publishing of his books, as well as provides important insights as to Leeser's concerns and difficulties with the congregation over his upcoming election in ten weeks

Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Isaac. Baltimore, MD, A one page letter from Zalma Rehine,a merchant and communal leader in Baltimore, Maryland, to his nephew Isaac Leeser. He writes of his bad cold and insomnia, and inquires about the pain in Leeser's side, suggesting that Leeser come to visit so his wife can take care of him

Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Isaac. Baltimore, MD, A short note from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore, Maryland to his nephew Isaac Leeser in Phildealphia, Pennsylvania. In this note he metions a "David", who has gone to Barkley Springs for his rumatic pain. He also mentions his vacation with his wife to the springs near Warrenton, Virginia

Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Isaac. Baltimore, MD, A three page letter from Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to his uncle Zalma Rehine in Baltimore, Maryland. In this detailed letter, Leeser writes to his uncle about family and friends, as well as about the effects of the financial Panic of 1837 on the economy, and Jewish businessmen in particular

Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Isaac. Warrenton, VA, A letter from Zalma Rehine in Warrenton, Virginia to his nephew, Isaac Leeser. He writes that he is vacationing with his wife, who is not well, near Barkley Springs, and describes his accomodations

Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Baltimore, MD, A letter from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore to both his nephews, Isaac and Jacob Leeser, in Philadelphia. In this letter, Rehine addresses Jacob in the third person, and encourages him to learn English.He goes on to encourage his good behavior so that he will do well in business and speaks of contacts that might be made for young Jacob Leeser

Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Baltimore, MD, A letter from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore to his nephew, Isaac Leeser, in Philadelphia. The letter discusses family news and the controversy caused by Mrs. Cohen, a member of a prominent Baltimore Jewish family, being inclined to the Christian church

Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Baltimore, MD, A letter from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore to his nephew, Isaac Leeser, in Philadelphia. This chatty letter contains the well-wishes of Leeser's relatives and friends, a Mr. and Mrs, N.T. Cohen

Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Baltimore, MD, A letter from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore to his nephew, Isaac Leeser, in Philadelphia. In this letter, Rehine describes his sadness at the loss of his brother in law, Barry Judah, and the pitiable mental state of his sister, Reinah Judah

Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Baltimore, MD, A letter from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore to his nephew, Isaac Leeser, in Philadelphia. In this letter, Rehine teases Leeser about his neglectful letter writing, and praises him for officiating at a recent wedding. He also sends the well wishes of friends in Baltimore to the notable Philadelphian Peixotto family. The letter has Rehine's full signature and is entirely in his hand

Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Baltimore, MD, A letter from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore to his nephew, Isaac Leeser, in Philadelphia. In this letter, Rehine wirtes about an Etting weddomg that Leeser did not officiate, and notes that Philip Cohen of Baltimore, the son of Israel I. Cohen, was pleased with one of Leeser's discourses

Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Baltimore, MD, A letter from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore to his nephew, Isaac Leeser, in Philadelphia. The letter is replete with well-wishes to Leeser from his friends and relatives. Zalma also asks that Leeser take care of himself and expresses his wish for the continued health of Isaac and his brother Jacob
Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Baltimore, MD, A signed note from Zalma Rehine to his nephew, Isaac Leeser, regarding business

Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Baltimore, MD, This one page letter to Isaac Leeser is from two writers in Baltimore. The first is from David Judah, noting that he is closing the castor oil business and asks Isaac to tell Solomon Levy to close out the oil in his hands at $1 or better. The second part is a note from Leeser's uncle, Zalma Rehine, mostly about bad business dealings with Mr. Jacobs. This is an unusually detailed business letter of Jewish commercial problems in the early part of the 19th Century

Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Philadelphia, PA, A letter from Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to his uncle, Zalma Rehine, in Baltimore, Maryland. In this letter, Leeser describes his anxiety at waiting to see if he has a posting with Mikveh Israel

Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Philadelphia, PA, A letter from Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to his uncle, Zalma Rehine, in Baltimore, Maryland. In this letter, Leeser describes his concerns that the Jews are being blamed for the financial Panic of 1837. Leeser goes on to discuss failures in New Orleans, and to send thanks to Philip Cohen of Baltimore for his literary support

Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Philadelphia, PA, A letter from Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to his uncle, Zalma Rehine, in Baltimore, Maryland. In this letter, Leeser describes his duties as Hazan at Mikveh Israel in vivid detail

Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Philadelphia, PA, A letter from Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to his uncle, Zalma Rehine, in Baltimore, Maryland. In this letter, Leeser outlines his contractual difficulties with the congregation of Mikveh Israel over a new three year contract

Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Philadelphia, PA, A letter from Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to his uncle, Zalma Rehine, in Baltimore, Maryland. In this letter, Leeser provides a detailed description of his campaigning for the minister's job at Mikveh Israel, after seven years as Hazan. It outlines the position of various key members and his strategy relative to them

Leeser, Isaac and Reinah, Judah. Baltimore, MD, A highly personal and well written letter from Reinah (Judah?) in Baltimore to Isaac Leeser. In it she complains of having few customers and little money, and asks Lesser for some financial help

Leeser, Isaac and Ridskopf, J. New York, NY, A printed broadside for Dr. J. Ridskopf's select male and female academy or classical English and commercial institute. On the reverse is a letter to Isaac Leeser, requesting a notice in the paper and asking for ad prices

Leeser, Isaac and Ritterband, L. M. New York, NY, A letter from Mrs. L. M. Ritterband in New York City to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. In this letter, Mrs. Ritterband relates the plight of her son, a skilled stone carver with a wife and six children. She asks Leeser to visit his shop when he is next in New York, and is clearly hoping that Leeser will mention his skills in the Occident
Leeser, Isaac and Roget, A. Baltimore, MD, A letter from A. Roget to Isaac Leeser regarding a subscription

Leeser, Isaac and Runkel, Philip. New Orleans, LA, A letter from Phillip Runkel, representing a Spanish-Portuguese synagogue in New Orleans, to Isaac Leeser. He writes that he is visitig New York City and would like to interview hazans while there. The letter is written on the letterhead of Robbins, Calhoun and Co., New York City

Leeser, Isaac and Salomon, D. Mobile, AL, A letter from D. Salomon of Mobile, Alabama to Isaac Leeser. In this letter, he details the consecration of Shaari Shomayin in Mobile. The letter also deals with Leeser's request for funds for his proposed Jewish Publication Society, Leeser's edition of the Pentateuch, and Salomon's request for Leeser to hold space in the Occident for his "short sermons."

Leeser, Isaac and Sampson, Emanuel. Philadelphia, PA, A letter from Emanuel Sampson to Rev. Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. In this letter, he asks that an act of kindness he received from Joseph Andrews, who offered a burial plot in Memphis, Tennessee to Sampson's child at no cost, be reported in the Occident

Leeser, Isaac and Samuel, B. M. Evergreen, AL, A letter from B.M. Samuel, the sole Jew in Evergreen, Alabama, to Isaac Leeser, asking for prayer books for himself and for a few other Jews in Claiborne, Alabama

Leeser, Isaac and Samuel, Frederick. Philadelphia, PA, A resolution written by Isaac Leeser, allowing the burial of Frederick Samuel to be buried at Mikveh Israel, despite the fact that he was not a member of Mikveh Israel

Leeser, Isaac and Samuel. Wilkes Barre, PA, Letter from Samuel in Wilkesbarre, PA to Isaac Leeser, expressing his wish to see a favorable article about American Jews in the Christian press reprinted by Leeser
Leeser, Isaac and Satz, A. J. St. Louis, MO, A letter from A. J. Satz to isaac Leeser, asking for a detailed list of subscribers so that he can collect

Leeser, Isaac and Schwarz, Joseph. New York, NY, This four page document is Leeser's translation of a letter in German he had received from Rabbi Joseph Schwarz in New York. In this letter, Schwarz, the leading Jewish authority of Palestinian matters at the time,writes a general appeal, formally soliciting an annual pledge of funds from synagogues for needs in Palestine

Leeser, Isaac and Seeligson, Michael. Galveston, TX, A letter written by Michael Seeligson (1797-1867) of Galveston, Texas, to Isaac Leeser, telling of his recent election as mayor of Galveston, Texas

Leeser, Isaac and Seeligson, Michael. Galveston, TX, A letter written by Michael Seeligson, the first Jewish mayor of Galveston, Texas, to Isaac Leeser. In this letter, he writes of the consecration of a Hebrew cemetary in Galveston

Leeser, Isaac and Seiling. Lancaster, PA, A letter from G. and J. Seiling Co. in Lancaster, Pennsylvania to Isaac Leeser, seeking the contract to paint his new synagogue, Beth El Emeth. They offer their credentials, experience, and enthusiasm for the job
Leeser, Isaac and Seimehoff, E. Reading, PA, A letter from E. Selmehoff, secretary of Obef Scholem, to Isaac Leeser, asking him to discontinue their ad for a teacher, as they have now secured one
Leeser, Isaac and Seligman, Jacob. New York, NY, A letter from Jacob Seligman, the librarian of the Hebrew Young Mens Literary Association, to Isaac Leeser regarding a subscription

Leeser, Isaac and Shway, Henry. Alexandria, VA, A letter from Henry Shway, the first secretary of the Beth El Hebrew congregation in Alexandria, Virginia, to Isaac Leeser, asking Leeser to note in his paper the formation of a congregation for the holidays

Leeser, Isaac and Simmons, M. B. St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, A letter from M.B. Simmons of St. Thomas to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. He writes of the difficulties in getting issues of the Occident, and notes that Mr. Carillon is again minister and that Reform changes have been made. He then describes a dream of meeting Leeser, but then being awakened by an earth quake

Leeser, Isaac and Simmons, M. B. St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, A letter from M.B. Simmons of St. Thomas to Isaac Leeser, informing him that he has just lost his young wife to consumption. He then brings Leeser up to date on the Jewish institutional difficulties onSt. Thomas, including the firing of the hazan, Mr. Carrillon. He concludes with book and newspaper matters

Leeser, Isaac and Simmons, W. B. St. Thomas, West Indies, A letter from M.B. Simmons of St. Thomas to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. He discusses writing James Henry in New York City for four cases of matzos and two sets of themurim. Additionally, he discusses selling Leeser's books
Leeser, Isaac and Slutsky, Louis. Buffalo, NY, A letter from Louis Slutsky in Buffalo, New York to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, informing him that he can do translations and is looking for a job
Leeser, Isaac and Soher, Solomon. Shougalo, MS, A letter from Solomon Soher in Shougalo, Mississippi to Isaac Leeser. Soher writes to turn down Leeser's request for a loan

Leeser, Isaac and Sollas, M. M. Jamacia, West Indies, A letter from Moses Mendes Sollas, a wealthy merchant, lay leader, and benefactor of K. K. Shahar Ashamaim in Kingston, Jamaica, to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. In this letter, he asks for information on a firm that can put up "spiced beef" for export to Jamaica. In addition, he gives his thoughts and advice to Leeser on his attempt to organize the broader jewish community in America. The last part includes book orders with names

Leeser, Isaac and Sollas, W. M. Kingston, Jamacia, A letter from Moses Mendes Sollas, a wealthy merchant, lay leader, and benefactor of K. K. Shahar Ashamaim in Kingston, Jamaica, to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. In this letter, Sollas thanks Leeser for being his spiritual teacher, since, being old men, he doubts they will ever meet again

Leeser, Isaac and Spanier, Louis. Albany, NY, A letter written by Louis Spanier of Albany, New York to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. In this letter, Spanier rails against Rabbi Isaac Mayer Wise and calls for his public censure. The letter is written in German with an English translation

Leeser, Isaac and Stein, D. Wheeling, WV, A letter from D. Stein in Wheeling, WV to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, PA. In this letter, he suggests that Leeser write to severl local Jews who refuse to accept his bible because they deny having subscribed. Also enclosed is a copy of the meeting of the Israelites of Wheeling

Leeser, Isaac and Stein, Daniel. Wheeling, WV, A letter from Daniel Stein in Wheeling, WV to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, PA. In this letter, Stein describes the Jewish activities in Wheeling, and tells of the election of Joel Eppinger as schochet, hazan, and teacher

Leeser, Isaac and Strouse, Isaac. Pittsburgh, PA, A letter from Isaac Strouse of Pittsburgh, PA to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, PA, asking to be informed of what he owes Leeser for the past three years of subscription. This letter provides a rare chronicle of the devastating Pittsburgh fire of 1845

Leeser, Isaac and Strouse, Isaac. Wilkes Barre, PA, A letter from Isaac Strouse in Wilkes Barre, PA to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, PA, describing the book he has written, a translation and interpretation of D. Ottensoser's work on Josephus, and why he considers it important. He asks if Leeser will review it and give his opinion, as well as mention it in the Occident

Leeser, Isaac and Strouse, Morris W. Wilkes Barre, PA, A signed letter from M. W. Strouse to Isaac Leeser, outlining the resolutions of the new congregation in Wilkes Barre, Pennsylvania. He continues with a request for prayer books to be sold at a commission
Leeser, Isaac and Tobais, Sophia. New York, NY, A note from Sophia Tobais in New York to Isaac Leeser, sending a report of the Ladies' Sewing Association, asking that it be published in the Occident

Leeser, Isaac and Tyler, Jas. P. Richmond, VA, A letter from Jas. P. Tyler of Richmond, Virginia to a young Isaac Leeser, informing him that he has given a letter of introduction to his friend Alexander Campell, and requesting that Leeser meet with him and his "sprightly single daughter"
Leeser, Isaac and Ullmann, Louis L. Cincinnati, OH, A letter from Louis L. Ullmann in Cinncinati, Ohio to Isaac Leeser. The letter is mostly in German

Leeser, Isaac and Valentine, S. Charleston, SC, A letter from S. Valentine to Rev. Isaac Leeser, forwarding a preamble and resolutions. It also includes a personal note that he will see him soon and that his family wishes to be remembered

Leeser, Isaac and Valentine, S. Charleston, SC, A letter from S. Valentine, the secretary of Shearith Israel, in Charleston, South Carolina to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania . The letter relates the religious conflict among the Jews of the city and complains that the Orthodox are being ridiculed

Leeser, Isaac and Waterman, Sigismond. New York, NY, A letter from Dr. Sigismond Waterman, the first Jewish medical graduate from Princeton, to Isaac Leeser, criticizing Leeser for his personal attack and for how poorly he reacts to debate

Leeser, Isaac and Weil, Solomon. New York, NY, A signed letter from Solomon Weil in New York to Isaac Leeser, sending $2.00 for his Occident and requesting previous issues. He also asks Leeser to insert notice in the next issue of his marriage

Leeser, Isaac and Weiskopf, Leopold. Charleston, SC, Letter to Isaac Leeser of Philadelphia from Leopold Weiskopf in Charleston, South Carolina, in regard to a bill for subscription he did not believe he owed

Leeser, Isaac and Wellen. San Francisco, CA, A gold rush era letter from Mr. Wellen, the postmaster in San Francisco to Isaac Leeser, informing him that eight Occidents were not picked up by Leeser's subscribers
Leeser, Isaac and Wise, I. M. New Orleans, LA, Printed letter addressed to Isaac Leeser, inviting him to the celebration of the tenth anniversary of the Home for Jewish Widows and Orphans

Leeser, Isaac and Wise, Isaac Mayer. Albany, NY, A letter from Rabbi Isaac Wise of Albany, New York to Rev. Isaac Leeser of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Written early in Wise's career, this letter hints at Rabbi Wise's strongly held opinions
Leeser, Isaac and Wise, Isaac Mayer. Albany, NY, A note from Rabbi Isaac Mayer Wise in Albany, New York to Rv. Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. It deals with the ordering of 24 books
Leeser, Isaac and Wise, Isaac Mayer. Albany, NY, A signed letter from from Isaac Mayer Wise to Isaac Leeser, explaining why he cannot collect any money for the Occident

Leeser, Isaac and Wise, Isaac Mayer. Albany, NY, A two and a half page letter from Isaac Wise in Albany, New York to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The letter contains a detailed attack on a previous article in the Occident by a person signed "Truth". Wise accuses the man of thinking in the narrow frame of a Chassid. Wise asks that his letter be published

Leeser, Isaac and Wise, Isaac Mayer. Albany, NY, A two and a half page letter from Isaac Wise in Albany, New York to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.This is the most important letter on the firsthand account of the "Congregation Beth-El of Albany Affair". (In 1850, a fistfight between Wise and the synagogue's president caused a split in the Albany community, and the consequent formation of a new congregation, the Anshe Emeth). Here Rabbi Isaac Wise writes in detail of the arguments at the Beth-El meeting in which he was discharged as Rabbi for leading the congregation toward a more liberal path. The letter mentions that a fight broke out, and the sheriff was called and he locked the building. Rabbi Isaac Wise identifies Louis Spanier as the instigator of the whole affair

Leeser, Isaac and Wise, Isaac Mayer. Albany, NY, A two page letter from Rabbi Isaac Wise of Albany, New York to Rev. Isaac Leeser of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The letter deals with the "Congregation Beth-El of Albany Affair," when Rabbi Isaac Wise was physically attacked on the bimah and a fight broke out. In this letter Rev. Wise outlines his seven point legal citory against Louis Spanier, who tried to remove Wise from Beth El

Leeser, Isaac and Wise, Isaac Mayer. Albany, NY, A two page letter from Rabbi Isaac Wise of Albany, New York to Rev. Isaac Leeser of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The letter deals with the "Congregation Beth-El of Albany Affair," when Rabbi Isaac Wise was physically attacked on the bimah and a fight broke out. In this letter one day after the fist fight, Rabbi Wise requests that Leeser publish an announcement about his ill treatment
Leeser, Isaac and Wise, Isaac Mayer. Cincinnati, OH, A letter from Rabbi Issac Mayer Wise to Isaac Leeser

Leeser, Isaac and Wise, Isaac Mayer. Cinncinati, OH, A letter from Isaac Mayer Wise in Cincinnati, Ohio to Isaac Leeser, sending him a copy of his newly published Israelite, lauding its initial success
Leeser, Isaac and Wolff, Adolph. Claiborne, AL, A short note from Wolff from Claibourne, Alabama to Isaac Leeser, sending payment for his subscription to the Occident
Leeser, Isaac and Wolff, Daniel. New Orleans, LA, Letter from Daniel Wolff in New Orleans to Isaac Leeser, annoucing the formation of the Hebrew Benevolent Society in New Orleans

Leeser, Isaac and Wolff, Daniel. New Orleans, LA, Letter from Daniel Wolff in New Orleans to Isaac Leeser, relating the news of the formation of a Jewish Benevolent Society in New Orleans. He then speaks of Rev. M.N. Nathan of Jamaica being engaged as minister of the Hebrew Portuguese Cong. in New Orleans at $2,500/year
Leeser, Isaac and Wolff, E. New York, NY, Letter from E. Wolff in New York City to Isaac Leeser. Enclosed are free tickets to the Ladies Fair, and a request for a contribution

Leeser, Isaac and Wolff, S. Mobile, AL, A letter written by S. Wolff of Mobile, Alabama to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. Enclosed with the letter is a check for $350, itemizing for Leeser how he wants the money to be dispensed for various personal reasons to people in Philadelphia

Leeser, Isaac and Wolff, S. Mobile, AL, A letter written by S. Wolff of Mobile, Alabama to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. Wolff relates in detail news of the suicide deaths of E.L. Andrews in Mobile, Alabama and his brother Z. Andrews of New Orleans, Louisiana

scopecontent.p: LSKAP0238_1r.tif; LSKAP0238_1v.tif; LSKAP0238_2r.tif; LSKAP0238_2v.tif; LSKAP0238_3r.tif; LSKAP0238_3v.tif

did.unittitle: Leeser, Isaac and Wolff, S. Mobile, AL, A letter written by S. Wolff, the Occident agent in Alabama, to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. In this letter Wolff references a financial loss of Leeser's and offers to help him through any immediate payments that must be made

Leeser, Isaac and Wolff, S. New York, NY, A two page letter from Isaac Leeser in New York to his friend and business associate Dr. S. Wolff in Philadelphia. The letter is a mix of detailed book business and his lecture tour

Leeser, Isaac and Wormser, A. Providence, RI, Letter signed by A. Wormser and B. Shuman, officers in the congregation of Providence, Rhode Island, to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. They are inquiring if funds are available from the late Judah Touro trust to help the Jews of Providence, Rhode Island to build a synagogue

Leeser, Isaac and Wurmser, B. Boston, MA, Letter from B. Wurmser in Boston to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. In this letter, he notifies Leeserof the election of officers in the first congregation in Boston. It also gives news of the school and the Ladies Hebrew Benevolent Society. The letter is written in German with an Enlgish translation

Leeser, Isaac. Chicago, IL, A letter from an unknown gentleman to Isaac Leeser. It announces the consecration of the first synagogue in the state of Illinois, Kehilath Anshe Ma'ativ. He notes that Israelites came from 150 miles around and that it was consecrated by Rev. S. M. Isaacs from New York City
Leeser, Isaac. New York, NY, Letter discussing Occident subscriptions
Leeser, Isaac. Philadelphia, PA
Leeser, Isaac. Philadelphia, PA, A letter from an unknown author to Isaac Leeser, written all in Hebrew cursive
Leeser, Isaac. Philadelphia, PA, A letter to Isaac Leeser from an unsigned subscriber to the Occident. The letter provides insightful comments on Rabbi Isaac Wise's articles in Leeser's Occident

Leeser, Isaac. Philadelphia, PA, Letter (1 of 3) signed by Solomon and Hart regarding Isaac Leeser's various orders of fancy silk and damask materials for Torah, Bimah, and Ark decorations of the synagogue. Apparently some of the material was to be returned if not needed or unsatisfactory

Leeser, Isaac. Philadelphia, PA, Letter (1 of 3) signed by Solomon and Hart regarding Isaac Leeser's various orders of fancy silk and damask materials for Torah, Bimah, and Ark decorations of the synagogue. Apparently some of the material was to be returned if not needed or unsatisfactory

Leeser, Isaac. Philadelphia, PA, Letter (1 of 3) signed by Solomon and Hart regarding Isaac Leeser's various orders of fancy silk and damask materials for Torah, Bimah, and Ark decorations of the synagogue. Apparently some of the material was to be returned if not needed or unsatisfactory
Leeser, Isaac. Philadelphia, PA, Letter announcing admission to the Pittsburgh Bar
Leeser, Isaac. Philadelphia, PA, Letter signed by Isaac Leeser to the teachers of the Educational Society school in Philadelphia
Leeser, Isaac. Philadelphia, PA, Manuscript fragment signed by L.R.J., found with Isaac Leeser's papers
Leeser, Isaac. Philadelphia, PA, Partially printed letter signed by the librarian of the Historical Society of Philadelphia, thanking Isaac Leeser for a bible

Lehman, Durr and Co. Montgomery, AL, Letter from Lehman, Durr, and Co., cotton factors and general commission merchants in Montgomery, Alabama. The letter concerns the prices for cotton in Mobile and New Orleans. This is the founding firm of Lehman Bros
Lehman, Fred and Lehman, Charles. Helena, MT, Letter regarding a butter and eggs merchant
Lehman, Stern and Co. New Orleans, LA, Bill from successors to Lehman Abraham and Co
Lehmann, A. New Orleans, LA, Letter from A. Lehmann, transmitting funds to a manufacturer in Columbia, Georgia

Lemle and Weil. Opelika, AL, Half sheet letterhead from Lemle and Weil, wholesale and retail dealers in staple and fancy dry goods, hats, boots, shoes, clothing and gents furnishing goods in Opelika, Alabama
Leszynsky, M. M. New York, NY, Letter from M.M Leszynsky, as physician of the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society, certifying that newly admitted children are free of infectious diseases
Levi, Jacob. San Francisco, CA, A Wells Fargo letter from Jacob Levi and Co., trying to find Louis Vogel of Santa Rosa Valley, who owes them $495.26
Levi, L. S. and Levi, M. A. Rochester, NY, Business letter on the letterheard of B. Levi and Sons with a picture of the father in a skull cap
Levy & Sons. New Orleans, LA, Signed letter from Levy and Sons regarding funds
Levy and Katzman. New York, NY, Letter on half sheet letterhead from Levy and Katzman, manufacturers of ladies and gents hand-sewn boots

Levy, Aaron. Philadelphia, PA, A two page letter written by Thomas Cooper (1759 - 1841) and sent from Northumberland, Pennsylvania to Aaron Levy, explaining why he can not pay his debt to Levy. Aaron Levy was a Revolutionary patriot, and founder of Aaronsburg, Pennsylvania

Levy, David C. and Tobias, T. J. Philadelphia, PA, A two page letter written by David C. Levy of Philadelphia to T.J. Tobias of New York. In ths letter, Levy thanks Tobias for his hospitality while in New York

Levy, Hayman and Tobias, Henry. Camden, SC, A letter from Hayman Levy, in Camden, South Carolina to Henry Tobias, in New York City. Levy speaks of his daughter and notes that she reciprocates his kind regards, in what is most likely a match-making letter
Levy, J. B. Pennsylvania, A four page Civil Ware era letter, written from the camp of the 16th Pennsylvania, from J.B. Levy. He talks of the war and the upcoming presidential election

Levy, Jacob Franks. Baltimore, MD, A letter from Jacob Franks Levy, son of Benjamin Levy, to William Augustine Washington (1757-1810), nephew of George Washington, in Westmoreland County, Virginia. In this detailed business letter, Levy discusses moneies owed to William Augustine Washington, were Levy acted as his agent. He speaks of the sale of shares and the price of crops. Additionally, he asks if Washington still has shares in the "Potomak Canal," as he has a buyer
Levy, Jake W. and Levy, Edward. Sherman, TX, A letter with the transmittal of a payment on the letterhead of Jake. W. Levy and Brother
Levy, John. New York, NY, A letter from John Levy of J. Levy and Co. to the Spring Grove Paper Co., requesting an order of card stock to be shipped for the manufacture of playing cards

Levy, Julius. San Francisco, CA, A letter to Congressman James Denver from George Johnston, a circuit court judge in San Francisco, asking for a presidential pardon for Julius Levy, who was convicted of smuggling cigars and suffers from poor health as a result of being in jail

scopecontent.p: doc_ja_dc_719_1r.tif; doc_ja_dc_719_1v.tif; doc_ja_dc_719_2r.tif; doc_ja_dc_719_2v.tif; doc_ja_dc_719_3r.tif; doc_ja_dc_719_3v.tif

did.unittitle: Levy, L. and Mincer, I. Waxahachie, TX, Letter with commercial content between L. Levy and I. Mincer

Levy, Levy Andrew and Gratz, Michael. Lancaster, PA, A letter written by Levy Andrew Levy and Joseph Simon in Lancaster, PA to Michael Gratz in Philadelphia, PA. It is signed by Levy Andrew Levy and with an "x" for Joseph Simon. The letter concerns inspections into the possibly irregular practices of the Army in disposing of the goods of Brizard Magruder, who was the brother of Levy's wife, Susannah. They write to Gratz to suggest tht he hire a lawyer. There is also a signed note by Michael Gratz
Levy, Levy Andrew. Lancaster, PA, A one page letter written by Levy Andrew Levy in Lancaster, Pennsylvania to J. Bullock, concerning a Lancaster, Pennsylvania lottery
Levy, Loeb and Scheuer. New Orleans, LA, Letter requesting cloth from a manufacturer in Columbia, Georgia
Levy, Mark & Brothers. New York, NY, Illustrated letterhead of Mark Levy and Brothers, importers of stationary, wafers, backgammon, chess men, playing and visiting cards of all kinds
Levy, Moses Elias. Miconopy, FL, A signed one page commercial letter written by Moses Elias Levy (1782-1854) in Miconopy, Florida, regarding land in Levy County. It was written from Miconopy, Florida
Levy, Moses Elias. Pilatka, FL, A signed one page commercial letter written by Moses Elias Levy (1782-1854) in Miconopy, Florida, regarding land in Levy County. It was written from Miconopy, Florida
Levy, Moses. Newport, RI, A letter from William Vernon to Capt. Cozzens, written from Newport, Rhode Island, requesting 313 pounds to be paid to himself and Moses Levy
Levy, Moses. Newport, RI, A letter written by William Vernon in Newport, RI, regarding an insurance claim on the Sloop Polly. It references Moses Levy as half owner of the slave ship
Levy, Moses. Philadelphia, PA, An angry letter written by Moses Levy (1756-1826) in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to W. S. Wallis of the same city, regarding money owed to Levy
Levy, Samuel. Trenton, NJ, Letter with the illustrated letterhead of S. Levy's Enterprise Cigar Factory in Trenton, NJ
Levy, Simon. Eufaula, AL, Letterhea of Simon Levy, successor to S. Waxelbaum
Levy, Zadig and Meyer, Theodore A. Newberry, SC, Letter from Theordore Meyer, responding to a complaint from Zadig Levy that he never received some knives that he had ordered from Meyer's store

Lewis, Isaac. Jefferson, TX, Half sheet letterhead from Isaac Lewish, wholesale retail dealer in fancy and staple dry goods, boots, shoes, hats, and clothing, to a Mr. Bailey in Boston, Mass. concerning a money draft payment
Lewy, Simon and Waxelbaum, S. Eufaula, AL, A letter regarding an order of cloth from Lewy and Waxelbaum, successors to S. Waxelbaum
Lichtenstein Brothers. New York, NY, Letter from the Lichtenstein Bros. and Co., cigar manufacturers
Liebovitz, S. New York, NY, Signed letter from S. Liebovitz

Lilienthal, David. Jerusalem, Palestine, A three page letter signed by a committee of American Jews living in Jerusalem, appointed by the American consul to solicit funds for impoverished Jews in Jerusalem. The committee consisted of David Lilienthal, Moses Teiler, and H. Z. Sneersohn. The letter is written to Col. Fisher in Washington D. C
Lipman, Julius. New York, NY, Letter to Julius Lipman regarding a property search
Livingston, John R. New York, NY, Letter discussing a purchase
Lob, Abraham. Ungstein, Germany, Poem in quatrains
Lob, Jacob. Ungstein, Germany, Letter mentioning Jacob Lob's wife, Madel Levi
Louis and Jessie and Children.
Lovenstein, William and Burgauer, J. Richmond, VA
Low, Frederick and Steinhart, Ign. San Francisco, CA, A letter to a bank in Carson City, explaining how the spot silver market works and why their price is lower
Lowenstein, B. Memphis, TN, Letterhead from B. Lowenstein and Bros. dry goods store in Memphis, Tennessee
Lowitz. Keokik, IA, Payment request for work done on a synagogue
Lowitz. Keokuk, IA, Letter discussing synagogue events
Lowitz. Keokuk, IA, Payment request for work done on a synagogue

Lyon, Robert and Morais, Sabato. New York, NY, A letter from Robert Lyon in New York to Rev. Sabato Morais, the Rabbi of Mikveh Israel in Philadelphia, in which Lyon asks for literary help from this well known religious leader. Robert Lyon was the publisher of the Asmonian, and an editor of the Mercantile Journal
M. B. Ochs & Sons. New York, NY, Short business letter with envelope from M.B. Ochs and Sons

Meyers, A. S. Memphis, TN, Printed letter from the district grand lodge no. 7 to all members, with minutes from the convention in New Orleans. Lists all the officers

Meylert, S. and Mailert, Augustus. Harrisburg, PA, A letter from S. Meylert from Harrisburg, PA to his nephew, Augustus Mailert in Richmond, Virginia. In the letter he discusses his recent farming success and invites his nephew to join him in similar land ventures

Meylert, S. and Mailert, Augustus. New Milford, PA, A letter from S. Meylert from New Milford, PA to his nephew, Augustus Mailert in Richmond, Virginia. In the letter he discusses his recent farming success and mentions his newphew's idea of moving from Richmond to Philadelphia to better himself and his children's education

Montefiore, Moses and Morais, Sabato. Ramsgate, England, A letter written by Moses Montefiore to Rabbi Sabato Morais of Mikveh Israel, Philadelphia, thanking Morais for his kind note lauding Montefiore on his efforts with the Sultan of Morocco on behalf of the oppressed Jews. It is written by a secretary and signed by Montefiore
Montefiore, Moses. England, A signed letter from Sir Moses Montefiore (1784-1885) to Mrs. Jones, returning a manuscript

Moog, A. and Moog, B. Mobile, AL, Signed letter from B. Moog, successor to A. and B. Moog, to the Urbana Wine Company

Moore, Henry. Philadelphia, PA, A stampless letter from Henry Moore, in Harrisburg to Daniel Agneco, in Beaver, Pennsylvania, regarding the appointment of engineers. Moore also mentions meeting a Mr. Moses, a Jewish banker in Philadlephia

Morais, Sabato and Almosnino, Sarah. London, England, A letter written by Sarah Almosnino from the Bevis Marks Synagogue, London, to Rev. Sabato Morais in Philadelphia. The letter is highly personal and deals with the death of her father, as well as other family matters

Morais, Sabato and Ezekiel, Jacob. Cincinnati, OH, A letter written by Jacob Ezekiel, Secretary of Hebrew Union College, to Rabbi Sabato Morais of Mikveh Israel, Philadelphia. This letter is related to the effort to have congregations join in a national union. Mikveh Israel refused to join

Morais, Sabato and Ezekiel, Jacob. Cincinnati, OH, A letter written by Jacob Ezekiel, Secretary of Hebrew Union College, to Rabbi Sabato Morais of Mikveh Israel, Philadelphia. This letter is related to the effort to have congregations join in a national union and speaks of plans to have the preparatory school for the Hebrew Union College in Philadelphia. Mikveh Israel refused to join

Morais, Sabato and Hart, Abraham. Philadelphia, PA, A letter written by the Parnis, Abraham Hart, to Rabbi Sabato Morais of Mikveh Israel, Philadelphia. In this Civil War era letter, Hart requests Morais to insert a prayer for the Union at all services for Saturday and holidays. the letter notes that it is a resolution of the Congregation
Morais, Sabato. Philadelphia, PA, A letter from Rabbi Sabato Henry Morais (1823-1897) to an attorney in New York City regarding the purchase of buildings
Morais, Sabato. Philadelphia, PA, A letter from Rabbi Sabato Henry Morais (1823-1897) to an attorney in New York City regarding the purchase of buildings

Morais, Sabato. Philadelphia, PA, A signed draft letter to the Sunday Dispatch by Rabbi Sabato Morais, supporting an article in the Israelite which supported some reform to the Jewish dogma. Here one sees the important transition to "American Modern Orthodoxy", led by Isaac Leeser and championed by Rabbi Sabato Morais of Mikveh Israel

Morais, Sabato. Philadelphia, PA, A signed letter from Rabbi Sabato Morais of Mikveh Israel in Philadelphia, PA to Mrs. Rose Smith. IN this letter, the Rabbi agrees to enlist ladies to help in the war effort
Morais, Sabto and Mendelsohn, J. Wilmington, NC, A letter to Rev. Sabato Morais in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, wishing him a good new year
Mordecai, Alfred. Washington, DC
Mordecai, G. W. Raleigh, NC, A brief Civil War era letter, in which the author mentions the french deserters from the Garibaldi Corps, part of the 39th infantry regiment in New York City

Mordecai, Sarah Ann and Hays, Richea. Philadelphia, PA, A letter written by Sarah Ann Mordecai (1805-1894) in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to her mother, Richea Gratz Hays, with the care of Samuel Etting in Baltimore, Maryland. The letter is replete with personal matters and speaks of Purim and the book of Ester. Sarah is the wife of Major Alfred Mordecai, the renowned expert in artillery

Mordecai, Sarah Ann and Mordecai, Laura. Washington, DC, A letter written by Sarah Ann Mordecai in Washington D.C. to her daughter Laura Mordecai in Philadelphia. The letter describes, among other things, a rare visit by the First Lady, Jane Appleton Pierce, as well as Sarah's clear commitment to Judaism. Sarah's aunt was Rebecca Gratz through her mother Richea Gratz Hays. Sarah is married to Major Alfred Mordecai the renowned expert in artillery
Moses & Singer. New York, NY, Letter discussing payment
Moses, Altamont. Sumter, SC, Letter with illustrated letterhead for Lehman, Stern and Co., successors to Lehman, Abraham and Co

Moses, I. W. and Moses, Horace. Philadelphia, PA, A letter from I. W. Moses (1821-1870), written from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to Horace Moses (1820-1893). The letter is replete with family detail and mentions Rebecca Gratz, the aunt who raised him, frequently
Moses, Isaac and Myers, Moses. New York, NY
Moses, Isaac. Philadelphia, PA, A letter from Isaac Moses (1742-1818) to James Duff, outlining the ownership of tartar cargo
Moses, J. and Moses, Julia. Philadelphia, PA, A letter from J. Moses to his wife, Julia L. Moses, care of J.L. and J. Joseph and Co
Moses, Max. New York, NY, A letter regarding bankruptcy
Moses, N. Portsmouth, NH, A letter with a stampless cover written to N. Moses, accepting a speaking engagement

Moses, Sara Gratz and Valentine, Phoebe Hays. Philadelphia, PA, A detailed and highly personal, four page letter from Sara Gratz Moses in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to Phoebe Hays Valentine in Montreal, Canada. It talks of Passover approaching and Sara's upcoming marriage to Jacob Henry Joseph of Montreal

Leeser, Isaac. Philadelphia, PA, Manuscript book of copied letters, all dated to April, 1856, from various individuals dealing with the debate as to whether the Mosaic Religion allows post-mortem examinations. In addition there are six pages of commentary that are not from a copied letter
Leeser, Isaac. Philadelphia, PA, Manuscript found with Isaac Leeser's papers. It discusses the heart of the controversy on Isaac Leeser’s translation of "I will be what I will be" Exodus 3:14

Leeser, Isaac. Philadelphia, PA, Printer's proof sheet of a Hebrew Commentary to be published in the Occident. Includes a proof type footnote by Leeser, where he identifies the Italian author of the Commentary
Leeser, Isaac. Philadelphia, PA, Subscriber list for the Occident in Leeser's hand. The list is divided into three columns with the 210 names listed under headings of cities and/or countries
Leeser, Isaac. Philadelphia, PA, This important manuscript, possibly in the hand of Isaac Leeser. The subject matter of this document is Leeser's exploration of the prophecy of the Messiah

Leider, Ben. New York, NY, An archive on Ben Leider, the first American volunteer to be killed in the Spanish Revolution of 1937. The archive includes a thirteen page booklet with his story, the Flying Reporter (Vol.1 No.3) issued by the Ben Leider Memorial Committee, the printed press release of his death, a Broadside of his death that shows letter and news paper reports, a photo of him with friends, a love letter by Ben Leider to S. Marshak at Cornell University and a second love letter to S. Marshak

Hart, Jacob. Easton, PA, Receipt describing a debt owed by Jacob Hart, which was used in a later court case

Hart, Michael and Hart, Jacob. Easton, PA, Four pages of business records for Michael Hart and his son Jacob Hart. The first page is for Michael Hart's general store in 1774. The latter three are fro ma distillery dated 1804 and 1805
Hart, Naphtali and Hart, Abram. Newport, RI, Receipt for three charges related to Naphtali Hart, received of Abraham Hart, and signed by Uriah Burke
Hart, Naphtali and Hart, Isaac. Newport, RI, Receipt signed by Joshua Isaacs on behalf of Napl. and Isaac Hart for 342 pounds and seven shillings
Hart, Naphtali. Newport, RI, Bill for eight boxes of spermacati candles sold to William Vernon by Naphtali Hart
Hart, Naphtali. Newport, RI, Bill with a list of stores to outfit the sloop Molly, sold to Master Joseph Rodman by Naphtali Hart
Hart, Naphtali. Newport, RI, Note payable with the signatures of Naphtali Hart and of William Vernon, a slave trader. This is an early transatlantic note at the start of the Spanish War
Hart, Naphtali. Newport, RI, Record of payments
Hays, Solomon and Samuel L. Hart. New York, Signed receipt for rations provided by George Copp, army contractor, to Solomon Says and Samuel L. Hart
Hess Brothers. Allentown, PA
Hirsh. Philadelphia, PA, Request on Wells Fargo Back in Carson City, Nevada to collect on a draft
I. M. Moss & Bro. Philadelphia, PA, A manifest for cargo bound from Philadelphia to Richmond
Isaacs, Isaiah. Richmond, VA, Receipt for a load of hay, signed by Richard Randolph III in Culrs Neck, Virginia. The transaction was through Mr. Isaacs, a merchant in Richmond
Isaacs, Solomon. Newport, RI, Receipt on the order of Solomon Isaacs, made out by Merchant Remington for William Vernon
Josephson, C. N. Abingdon, VA, Handwritten receipt of purchases by Miss N. Montgomery
Judah, Benjamin. New York, NY, Receipt for wine from John Hertell to Benjamin Judah (1760-1831) in New York City, signed on back by Judge Robert Morris
Kokernot, David Levi. Gonzales County, TX, Tax receipt for David Levi Kokernot, a large ranch owner
L. H. Hershfield & Bro. Helena, MT, Memorandum of gold deposit at the U.S. Assay office at New York by L. H. Hershfield of Helena, Montana

Leeser, Isaac and Leeser, Jacob. Baltimore, MD, A letter from Jacob Leeser to his brother Isaac Leeser. Letters from Jacob Leeser are rare, as much of Leeser's personal family correspondence was destroyed at his death
Leeser, Issac. Philadelphia, PA, Printed ink receipt in Leeser's hand for a one year subscription to the Occident
Leixas, Benjamin.
Levit, Simon and Shrage, Charles. Philadelphia, PA, A printed receipt for $1.00 for a brick for Congregation Agudath Israel, of Darby and Collingdale, Pennsylvania. In English and Yiddish

Levy, Ferdinand. New York, NY, A document signed by Ferdinand Levy, brother of Alfred and Benjamin Levy, for the receipt of the deserter Francis Bonet of Company K of the Enfans Perdus regiment in New York
Levy, Ira W. Trenton, NJ, A receipt for the mustering of George Lauff for $680.00, signed by Captain Ira W. Levy of the 13th New Jersey volunteers
Levy, Ira W. Trenton, NJ, A receipt for the mustering of John McDowell for $720.00, signed by Captain Ira W. Levy of the 13th New Jersey volunteers
Levy, M. and Hart, N. Newport, RI, A receipt from Newport, Rhode Island, noting fees due by various merchants. M. Levy and L. Hart are listed as creditors
Levy, M. and Hart, N. Newport, RI, Note regarding payment

Levy, M. Port Gibson, MS, An early war-era Conferderate requisition invoice, where M. Levy sold checkered shirts, carpet bags, and other sundry military-related goods to the "Fair View Rifles" (16th Mississippi)
Levy, Moses and Hart, Naphtali. Newport, RI, A receipt for 75 fathoms of cable to Moses Levy, signed by Naphtali Hart

Levy, Moses. Newport, RI, A receipt for a consignment of wine and rum to the ship Molly, signed by Moses Levy (1704-1792), a prominent merchant and trader in Newport. RI and New York, NY. The ship belonged to the Vernons and was a known Slave ship
Levy, Moses. Newport, RI, Four page account of the work done for Moses Levy (1704-1792) for his brigeteene, refitting the ship. It was paid for by Moses Levy and William Vernon to Timothy Peckhams
Levy, Moses. Newport, RI, Receipt to Moses Levy (1704-1792), a prominent merchant and trader in Newport. RI and New York, NY
Levy, Nathan. Philadelphia, PA, A receipt with the signature of Nathan Levy, son of the Baltimore patriot, Benjamin Levy
Levy, Nathan. Saint Thomas, A certificate of landing as American Consul on St. Thomas (1818-36), signed twice by Nathan Levy
Levy, Samson. Philadelphia, PA, Bill for Samuel Wallis for items purcahsed from Samson Levy, a prominent merchant in Philadelphia during the Colonial Period
Levy, Solomon. New York, NY, Hand written receipt from First Lady Martha Washington for twenty pounds of cotton, signed by Solomon Levy
Levy, W. I. New York, NY, Receipt of payment from J. Geo. Harris to the U.S. Navy Yard

Marks, I. H. stockton, CA, Hand written receipt to charity lodge no. 6 for a ten dollar loan to I.H. Marks to allow him to travel to San Francisco, signed by Marks

Maurice, Salomon. New Orleans, LA, A receipt in French with a US excuse tax stamp for the death certificate of Salomon Maurice, embossed with the seal of the recorder of births and deaths for the parish of New Orleans
Meyers, Abraham C. New Orleans, LA, Receipt for lumber shipped to Texas, signed by Abraham C. Meyers
Mickve Israel. Philadelphia, PA
Mickve Israel. Philadelphia, PA, Blank receipts from Mickve Israel for the rental of a seat
Monis, Judah. Cambridge, MA

Moses, Isaac. New York, NY, A receipt from Isaac Moses for a chest of Bokea tea, sold to Samuel Gilford

Moss, Edward and Tobias, T. I. Philadelphia, PA, Two penned letters and an invoive concerning shipments of wines and champagnes as well as the sales of wines and champagnes at auction. All are addressed to T. I. Tobias of New York, and involve the noted Jewish merchants Joseph and Edward Moss
Myer, Jacob. Philadelphia, PA, Rare pawn ticket missing the revenue stamp
Myers, Aaron. Sharpsburg, VA, Receipt for hay and corn
Myers, Moses. Norfolk, VA, Note payable to Wachsmuth, one of the most important merchant shippers south of the potomac
Neafie and Levy. Philadelphia, PA, Receipt from steam engine and boiler works company
Neafie, Jacob and Levy, John P. Philadelphia, PA, Manifest for cargo clearing Philadelphia customs for the steam ship, the Pocahantas, of Neafie and Levy Ship and Engine Building Co
Phillips, D. and Hendricks, Henry. New York, NY, Receipt for seat rental at Shearith Israel for D. Phillips
Phillips, D. and Tobias, Frederick M. New York, NY, Receipt issued to Frederick M. Tobias to the Trustees of the Congregation Shearith Israel

Phillips, Napthali. New York, NY, Receipt for 43 months subscription from May 5, 1820 to Dec 15, 1823 to the assignees of Napthali Phillips, the first Jewish newspaper publisher, for the National Advocate
Polock, Isaac. Newport, RI, Receipt signed by Isaac Polock (1700-1764) of New Port, Rhode Island. He was one of the founders of the Tuoro Synagogue

Rodrigues, Isaac. Philadelphia, PA, Rent receipt of monies from Mrs. Gashill signed by Isaac Rodrigues
Rohelia, Emanuel. Adams County, MS, Partly printed document of the taxes of Emanuel Rohelio on his 11 slaves signed by G. W. Lancaster printed at the Mississippi Free Trade office
Roscover, H. Corry, PA, Printed hand filled promise to pay dues for members in the Indpendent Order of B'nai B'rith, Ahaveth Sholem Lodge, founded in 1871 signed by financial secretary
Rosenburger, Henry. Philadelphia, PA, Receipt of Farmers' Hay and Straw Market Association Hay Scales
Rosengarten and Etting. Philadelphia, PA, Receipt book with numerous Jewish names listed with fees acquired from the manuscripts of William Sellers Iron Manufacturer
